Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 04:45PM ButterflyLady wrote: I think we should be whatever we want to be.  I am positive most days but I have days that are dark, sad and filled with worry.  If you can't deal with my bad days then you sure don't deserve to be around me with my good.  When you are stage 4, it changes everything.  It changes how I view life and the future.  I didn't want this but it's the cards I was dealt.  I do try to be positive most of the time, just becuase if I didn't, I would cry all the time.  Humor is how my family deals with things and that helps.  I do get tired of people of people saying, "you look great", "keep your chin up", "stay positive".  I mean really, how great can you look when you are bald, boobless, pale, circles under your eyes, and how can anyone stay upbeat and positive all the time.  I am human, not a superwoman.  I have bad days and good days.  I am so thankful for my good days and I hate that my son has to deal with my bad days, but it is what it is.  I want to live as long as I can but at the same time I don't want to spend what remaining time I have sick in the bed all the time.  That is no living.  Don't let anyone tell you how you should feel or act.  Just be you and feel what you feel.  This is your life.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2014 03:23PM butterflylady2 wrote: Looks like this is an old topic, but I was looking everywhere for this.  Doctors won't supply much info on this and I like to study before making a decision.  I had DCIS high grade PR & ER + and HER2- in 2012; had 2 lumpectomies.  No additional treatment.  The 2nd procedure in 2012 with the stereotactic wire placement in radiology before surgery, overcompressed my breast, causing my 2nd go around with RSD (previously in R. wrist/hand after fracture-improved through time and P.T.).  45 days with severe allodynia, unable to tolerate the softest fabric; sharp jabbing pains, etc. Now 2014, Invasive Ductal Carcinoma same breast; Two June surgeries. First one lymphadenectomy (clear) with very painful nerve damage felt like needles constantly under my arm, but after 33 days, that is easing up.  2nd one in June to get clearer margins, produced a terrible flareup of RSD in breast and am waiting for improvement to be able to tolerate any clothing, etc.  Recommended additional treatment is 5 day brachytherapy with catheter directed at the cavity where the tumor was and then 5 yrs of hormonal treatment.  Have been very concerned about causing another RSD flareup, as I am having difficulty getting through this one.  Also, concerned whether partial breast radiation will provide enough protection from rogue cells.  Thanks for "listening" to my story.

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2012 10:32PM Butterflylady2012 wrote: Hi Chrissera,  LIke you, I am a new lady who was just told she has BC, on Thursday.  They say they found early which I am extremely thankful.  So far, I am a low-grade ILC (Invasive Lobular Carcinoma) in right breast.  MRI next week.  BRCA testing still to be done.  Had blood work and chest x-ray yesterday.   No surgery date yet, but dr. said could be month away.  I have another area on same breast they will biopsy.  MRI will show more, so as we all do...I just wait.  Luckily I am able to sleep relatively well so far, but I think as I get closer to surgery my sleep patterns will change.  Please dont feel that you have to be strong for everyone, especially now. I tend to do that too and it only hurts us.  You hide the fear and it hurts your ability to cope day by day.  Nobody is a rock.  Nobody.  My dear mother is 70 and has had her own major health issues (benign brain tumors) for 20 years.  If she can endure, so can I.  It wasn't cancer, but she has been put to hell and back.  Yes, I am a bit strong for her sometimes, but I try not to hide my fear.  She knows I am scared.   As far as working through treatment, like you I am unsure.  At this point, it sounds like surgery and radiation, no chemo, but I don't know if things will change.  Through treatments I plan to work,but I don't know how I will react.  I tend to be sensitive to medications and such, so I hope my body takes the radiation smoothly. I'm curious what others say about treatment side effects. You are so right, this site is a blessing indeed..

Posts.Content: May 23, 2012 10:48PM Butterflylady2012 wrote: 7 days post-op and will be seeing PS tomorrow, Oncologist and General Surgeon Friday.  Here was what my Pathology report said.  First note, tumor was smaller then expected!  Secondly, They took 4 nodes, all clear.  Huge relief!  He explained to me something though, or I would have been concerned in my initial reading of the report.  In one node they found 139 cancer cells, but said 200 cells is actually what they said most doctor's consider a positive node and microscopic in nature.  Mine was far below was is even recognized as positive.  Before I see oncologist on Friday though, my case goes before a "tumor board" or committee which reviews all cases.  Looks like I will not have to deal with Lymphedemia though or those other issues...thank god! Story which is sweet and a bit funny.  Went to Safeway yesterday with mom and saw co-worker who had not seen me since I left work.  She had been on vacation and when she got back I was gone.  She is quite a bit younger then me (by over 20 years), hugged me an hugged me AND hugged me, kissed my cheek and almost crying and I was starting to cry because I wasn't expecting the emotion from her.  BUT she hugged me so hard, my mom was gently pushing her away because he was hurting me (not meaning or knowing it).  She squeezed the stuffings out of me!  But Ouch!  Now today I feel a bit more sore, but the hug and caring from her was was worth it. :) Prayers and hugs to all the rest of the May surgeries.  To be on the other side of the surgery has been a huge weight off my shoulders.  Keep us posted and share what is happening!  We are all with you!

Posts.Content: May 20, 2012 07:49AM Butterflylady2012 wrote: Recuperating from surgery on 16th, one day at a time.  Stayed over 2 nights, ran slight temp increase and 2nd night had fever of 101, but then broke and no fever since.  Energy comes and goes.  Went for VERY short walk yesterday, but good to get out.  By early afternoon was beat and took a nap.  Only one drain where right breast was.  CCs going down each day.  Surgeon took out 7 nodes, but said that all were in cluster "like grapes" and so he just took them out together.  Very easy and no drains under arm.  He said from initial check nods look benign (were clear during initial MRI as well) and pathology report should be in a day or two.  Told I will never again be able to have IV, or give blood, or have BP taken on that arm.  Thinking of having ID bracelet made.  If I can't tell someone, how would they know.  Hope everyone is doing okay.  With help of my mother going to take first "shower bath" today.  Going to put shower chair in tub/shower, fill tub slightly and simply rinse myself that way.  I don't want to risk even with hand held nozzle getting water on stitches.  Just to rinse a little will feel good.  Take care, I'll check back soon.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 04:57PM Butterflylady2012 wrote: I just finished going through the biopsy this morning.  Glad it is over, but glad I was able to get in so quickly.   It was not painful necessarily, but uncomfortable and having to stay in one position and still for so long.  The position compressed my breathing a bit and when you are stressed, that doesn't help.  They actually had to do a second round of pokes, because some of the first ones weren't as good as they'd like.  Yuck!  Since my breasts are so dense I guess the needle had trouble cutting through the tissue.  Dense with a couplie "D"!  The assistant stood next to me though almost the whole time, ensuring I did not move, but also holding my hand.  Really appreciated her extra care, she was nice! I was proud of myself, I think I did pretty well.  The doctor said that they are still leaning towards benign, fibrocystic she called it, but they said we are not Pathologists and we will only know then. I saw a zoom this morning of the 2011 Mammo and the one last week and you can really see the difference between the two.  Most of the clustered calc's were not there last year and now bamm a bunch in one area.  There are definitely several tightly clustered white spots.  Icoupontosavmoney - thank you for your comment about Googling, it is really easy to do these days and I have been doing a bit much, momzr - I am hoping for less dense breasts after menopause as well.  I hope this will prove bengin and I can simply go for regular screenings to keep on top of them, but not necessarily have to worry about them.  Thanks to all for the input - glad the first stage is over, now just waiting.  They say between 3-5 days to hear back.  I'm now going to drink my Starbucks and just relax, try not to worry about something I cannot control.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2012 05:02AM Butterflylady2012 wrote: Hi Ladies, Thanks for the thread! I was trying to find a thread for Chemo, no Chemo decision.  I have battled this decision for over a week and finally made my decision this weekend.  No Chemo.  I am 43 and was Dx'd with ILC in April.  Stage 2, grade 2, 3 cm tumor, node negative, ER+,PR+, Her2neu. Right sided mastectomy in May and after more findings in right breast after Pathology looked at it, I will be having left breast removed in very near future as precaution.   My Oncotype score came back 14.  Oncologist said after hormone therapy we are looking at 9.  Chemo would have only reduce by 2%.  My Oncology team, as well as an expert at UCSF they went consulted with, felt very comfortable if I chose no Chemo.  If we were looking at even a 5% reduction, my Oncologist said he'd be pushing it more in my case, but it is not.  I battled with it for awhile and finally felt that this was the best decision for me overall and with the backing of my doctors.  Too low risk reduction for the Chemo SE's and problems that could happen.  My system tends to be sensitive to meds and reactions.  Even though I am still a bit nervous and know the risk is always there, I feel good about my decision.   My thoughts and prayers to all ladies here!  We don't want to be here, but we will get through this, taking it one step at a time!

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 02:05PM Butterflylady2012 wrote: Hi Michelle, Just one more thought.  Yes, your mind will take you to the worse case scenarios initially.  It is very natural.  Because you don't have the facts yet, your brain tries to fill in the blanks, tries to give answers to the question marks.  The fear takes over.  I know your emotions probably feel like a rollercoaster right now.  You feel scared, angry, many emotions all at once.  I was googling so much it was getting out of hand.  Try to distract yourself a little if you can.  Take a walk, visit a friend, go to a movie.  I know it's hard and you might not want to, but sometimes the distraction does help if only for an hour.  Vent all you need to, we will listen... Butterfly (Sharon)

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2013 02:24AM ButterflyLady wrote: I did  taxol 8 years go when I was first diax.  This time I have liver mets.  Hormone treatments didnt' work for me either.  I have been on taxotere, halaven, and now on afinitor in the last 11 months.  I had a scan done today and it showed some progression but not sure how much til I talk to my doctor next Tuesday.  If the progression is less than 30% growth then I stay on afinitor for another 6 weeks to give it time to see if it is workng.  I have been on it for 6 weeks already.  If the growth is more than 30%, then I will come off the trial.  Not much left for me to try.  My liver mets have been very aggressive.  I am just trying to live each day to the the fullest.  I pray that the taxol works for you.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2013 04:17PM Butterflylady2012 wrote: Wow, we have a big March group!  Hello there Ladies, well I know those with March surgeries are on the time clock now until their surgeries.  Mine is March 20th at 7:30 AM.  We have to be at hospital at 5:30!  I'm not worried about me, I'll be knocked out in 2 hours after arrival, but my mother and boyfriend will have a very long day and one of my brothers and his wife I've said it's fine to come once I'm in surgery...no need to get there so early!  Even though I did this before last May for right sided Mx and TE placement, I find I am getting more nervous now.  It's just been a long year. I find I'm talking about it more to friends and such, because I know I am reaching out for someone to give words of support.  Or maybe the more I talk it won't seem so scary.  Again, I've been through it already, but I'm still losing another body part!  I am having preventative on the left side now.  I feel thankful every day though that I am not losing an arm, a leg....etc... Nikstar, hang in there!  For my first surgery I was a wreck, but I also got a meditation CD to help me relax a bit (It was recommende to me on this site).  I kept saying calming things to myself before surgery and when they were wheeling me in.  It did help a bit.  I even took some anti-anxiety meds at the time ( still do actually).  Don't be afraid to get all the help you can get and deserve!  This is a HUGE weight and you need help.  I hope you have support around you and hugs.  We are here for you.  Come say whatever you need to and we are with you!! Thinking of Keke today with her surgery today....healing thoughts her way!  Butterflylady (Sharon)
